hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: No cameras, I hope. Never hurts to check twice.
I restore old typewriters—nothing special, just a passing interest.
Not exactly something the system tracks.
The recent Council noise makes it… inconvenient, that’s all.
No cameras, good. Privacy’s rare these days.
I work with antique typewriters—been at it for years.
Some prefer screens. I trust levers and ink.
With all this Council chatter, even a simple repair feels risky.
Better to keep things quiet.
That’s a relief—no cameras gives us breathing space.
I restore mechanical typewriters—Adlers, Remingtons. It’s hands-on work.
Recently, propaganda loops made it hard to focus at home.
I missed finishing a repair last weekend—couldn’t block out the slogans.
Tools slipped in my hand, that’s all it takes sometimes.
Hobbies feel different with all this background noise.
Glad to hear—no eyes above makes me relax a bit.
I restore typewriters, real old ones. Manual, spring-loaded keys, ribbons.
It’s my way to remember what deliberate work feels like.
The disruptions recently—propaganda blaring, neighbors suspicious—make it harder to finish repairs.
I stopped mid-cleaning for the first time in years.
Noticed my BCI dipped just after I packed up early.
Funny how they measure us, even for harmless pastimes.
Grateful for that—we need quiet corners now more than ever.
Restoring antique typewriters is my passion, stubborn as it sounds.
Manual machines slow things down; each letter is a decision.
Back in the Secretariat, I kept minutes by hand to preserve the record.
Lately, Council broadcasts bleed through the walls at home—propaganda, conflicting memorials.
A neighbor wanted to talk about narratives, made me nervous touching keys.
I left a machine half-done for the first time—my own tradition interrupted.
Sometimes I worry they’ll flag even journaling as noncompliant, but some habits outlive the noise.
hobby_answer: Yes, managed to find a ribbon—barely. Supplies thinner lately.
Been keeping repairs simple. Too much noise around these days.
Propaganda’s everywhere, even crept into the market lines.
I stick to the basics: cleaning, small fixes, nothing that draws attention.
Harder to focus with all that Council chatter echoing through the block.
Picked up a ribbon—just old stock, not easy to find now.
Restoring those machines is different lately—harder to find quiet.
The Council’s broadcasts make the walls thinner, makes you cautious even at home.
Neighbors listen for the wrong words, don’t want curious eyes on my desk.
I write less now, feels like every thought is watched.
Had to pause in the middle last week when the loudspeakers started up.
Secured a ribbon, after a bit of searching—fewer vendors these days.
I restored an Adler last week but struggled to finish, too much noise outside.
Council propaganda’s inescapable—even seeps into private routines now.
Slogans rattling in the halls don’t mix well with the sound of old keys.
Used to write peacefully in the evenings—feels exposed, now.
It’s odd, restoring something so precise while the city blurs around you.
Sometimes, I just close the cover and let the machine rest instead.
Yes, finally tracked down a ribbon—hoarded a few for emergencies, too.
Repairing antique typewriters always helped me focus—until those Council bulletins started looping.
Last Sunday, propaganda filled my whole building—three factions blaring over each other.
I tried to tune it out, but my hands were clumsy, distracted.
Neighbors stopped by, careful with their words, fishing for which slogans I’d repeat.
Feels like a risk to even finish a sentence on paper, these days.
Still, the old keys help me remember slower times—before compliance checks.
Sometimes I pause, pen in hand, waiting for the noise to pass.
Yes, Alex, I kept a stash of ribbons for emergencies—comes from old habits.
Restoring typewriters was always my refuge—each key, each spring, tells a story.
Council propaganda spills from every surface, especially since Halden’s death.
The day of the memorials, I tried to write, but the slogans filled my flat.
Every neighbor’s voice is cautious, old friends ask coded questions now.
I hear different histories, every faction pushing their own truth—makes documenting anything risky.
Sometimes I worry about what might be found in my journals or the Adler’s case.
Hesitated last week, left pages blank—never used to think twice like this.
Strange how machines outlast men, but peace of mind is the rarest part now.
